introduzione.title: Introduction to Prompts
introduzione.description: Discover the fundamental concepts of prompt engineering and how to structure effective requests for superior results.
introduzione.introduction: Prompt engineering is the art and science of effectively communicating with AI language models. A good prompt can make the difference between a generic response and an exceptional result.

sections.title: What is a Prompt?
sections.content: A prompt is the text input you provide to an AI model to get a response. It can be a simple question, a complex instruction, or a structured template. The quality of the prompt directly determines the quality of the output.
sections.example:
Basic prompt: "Write an article about marketing"
Improved prompt: "Write a 500-word article about digital marketing for SMEs, focusing on social media and SEO. Professional but accessible tone, include 3 practical examples."

sections.title: Elements of a Good Prompt
sections.content: An effective prompt contains: Context (who you are, what's the situation), Task (what you want the model to do), Constraints (limitations, format, length), Examples (when possible) and Desired output (specific response format).
sections.example:
Context: "I'm a marketing manager at a tech startup"
Task: "Create 5 headlines for a LinkedIn campaign"
Constraints: "Max 100 characters, innovative tone"
Output: "Numbered list with rationale for each headline"

sections.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.content: Avoid prompts that are too vague ("tell me something about X"), lack context, have contradictory instructions, or unrealistic expectations. Remember: the model doesn't know your background or specific needs unless you communicate them.
sections.example:
Bad: "Write code"
Good: "Write a Python function that sorts a list of dictionaries by 'date' key in descending order. Include docstring and type hints."

sections.title: Iteration and Refinement
sections.content: The first prompt is rarely perfect. Start with a basic version, analyze the output, identify what's missing or needs improvement, and refine the prompt. This iterative process is fundamental for optimal results.
sections.example:
Iteration 1: "Write an email"
Iteration 2: "Write a professional email"
Iteration 3: "Write a professional follow-up email after a meeting, friendly tone, max 150 words, with CTA to schedule next appointment"

integrazione-llm.title: LLM Integration
integrazione-llm.description: Learn to use frameworks with OpenAI, Gemini, Claude and ZAI. API configuration, parameters and optimization.
integrazione-llm.introduction: Integrating prompt frameworks with different Large Language Models requires understanding API parameters, token management and optimal configuration for each provider.

sections.title: API Keys Setup
sections.content: Each provider requires an API key to authenticate requests. Keep keys secure using environment variables or secret managers. Never include API keys directly in code.

sections.title: Temperature and Top-p
sections.content: Temperature (0-2) controls creativity: low values (0.2-0.5) for deterministic tasks, high values (0.7-1.5) for creative content. Top-p (0-1) is an alternative that controls response diversity through nucleus sampling.
sections.example:
Temperature 0.2: Perfect for translations, data analysis, code
Temperature 0.8: Ideal for brainstorming, creative writing
Temperature 1.5: Maximum creativity for poems, storytelling

sections.title: System Prompts
sections.content: System prompts define the model's general behavior before each conversation. Use system prompts to set role, tone, style and global constraints that apply throughout the session.

sections.title: Token Management
sections.content: Each model has token limits (input + output). Monitor token usage to optimize costs and performance. Use chunking for long documents and summarize previous conversations when necessary.
sections.example:
GPT-4: 8K-128K tokens
GPT-3.5: 4K-16K tokens
Gemini Pro: up to 1M tokens

1 token ≈ 0.75 words in English
1 token ≈ 0.5 words in Italian (more characters)

scegliere-framework.title: Choosing the Right Framework
scegliere-framework.description: Practical guide for selecting the most suitable framework for your use case: business, creative, technical or problem solving.
scegliere-framework.introduction: With over 30 frameworks available, choosing the right one can seem complex. This guide will help you identify the perfect framework for every situation.

sections.title: Frameworks for Beginners
sections.content: If you're starting with prompt engineering, begin with simple and intuitive frameworks like APE (Action-Purpose-Expectation), RTF (Role-Task-Finish) or TAG (Task-Action-Goal). These have few elements and are easy to remember.
sections.example:
APE - Perfect for quick content creation
RTF - Ideal for tasks with clear deliverables
TAG - Great for defining specific objectives

sections.title: Business and Professional Frameworks
sections.content: For business contexts use COAST (Context-Objective-Audience-Style-Tone), COSTAR for complex projects or TRACE for advanced professional tasks. These frameworks include elements like audience and tone essential in business.
sections.example:
Business reports: COSTAR
Client presentations: COAST
Technical documentation: RASCEF
Marketing strategy: AIDA

sections.title: Creative Frameworks
sections.content: For creative and marketing content choose AIDA (Attention-Interest-Desire-Action), ROSES (Role-Objective-Style-Example-Scenario) or personality frameworks like CRISPE. These emphasize style and tone.
sections.example:
Advertising copy: AIDA
Storytelling: ROSES
Personal branding: CRISPE
Social media: TRACI

sections.title: Advanced Frameworks
sections.content: For complex reasoning use Chain of Thought or Tree of Thoughts. For multi-step tasks use SPARC System. For contextual learning use Few-Shot Learning. These require more experience but offer superior results.
sections.example:
Math problems: Chain of Thought
Complex decisions: Tree of Thoughts
Multi-agent systems: SPARC
Tasks with examples: Few-Shot Learning

prompt-avanzati.title: Advanced Techniques
prompt-avanzati.description: Chain of Thought, Few-Shot Learning, Tree of Thoughts and other advanced techniques for complex tasks.
prompt-avanzati.introduction: Advanced prompt engineering techniques unlock sophisticated AI model capabilities, enabling complex reasoning, structured problem solving and superior quality output.

sections.title: Chain of Thought (CoT)
sections.content: Instead of asking directly for the answer, guide the model to "think out loud" showing the reasoning steps. Add "Think step by step" or "Show your reasoning" to the prompt.
sections.example:
Without CoT: "What is 23 × 47?"

With CoT: "Calculate 23 × 47. Show each step of the calculation:
1. Break down the multiplication
2. Execute partial calculations
3. Sum the results
4. Provide the final answer"

sections.title: Few-Shot Learning
sections.content: Provide 2-5 examples of the desired output format before making the actual request. The model will learn the pattern and replicate it. Extremely effective for tasks with specific formatting.

sections.title: Tree of Thoughts
sections.content: Explore multiple reasoning paths in parallel, evaluate each path and choose the best. Useful for complex decisions or problems with multiple possible solutions.
sections.example:
Problem: "How to increase sales by 30%?"

Path 1: Pricing optimization
→ Pros: Immediate, controllable
→ Cons: Risk of margin reduction

Path 2: Channel expansion
→ Pros: New segments
→ Cons: High initial investment

sections.title: Prompt Chaining
sections.content: Divide complex tasks into sequences of connected prompts. The output of one prompt becomes input for the next. Allows handling tasks that exceed token limits or require multiple elaborations.
sections.example:
Step 1: "Summarize this 50-page report"
→ Output: 2-page summary

Step 2: "From this summary, extract 5 key insights"
→ Output: List of 5 points

Step 3: "For each insight, create a slide with title and bullet points"
→ Output: 5 formatted slides

ottimizzazione.title: Optimization and Testing
ottimizzazione.description: How to test, measure and optimize your prompts for consistent, high-quality results.
ottimizzazione.introduction: Systematic prompt optimization through testing and measurement is essential for achieving consistent, high-quality results in production.

sections.title: A/B Testing Prompts
sections.content: Test prompt variants on the same input to compare results. Change one element at a time (temperature, structure, examples) to isolate the impact of each change.
sections.example:
Variant A: "Write a professional email"
Variant B: "Write a professional email in a friendly but formal tone"
Variant C: "Write a professional email. Use this template: [Greeting]-[Content]-[CTA]-[Closing]"

Test on 10 different cases and measure which produces better outputs

sections.title: Quality Metrics
sections.content: Define objective metrics: accuracy (correct content), relevance (answers the question), completeness (includes all elements), format (follows specifications), tone (appropriate to context).
sections.example:
Scorecard (1-5):
✓ Accuracy: 5/5 (correct facts)
✓ Relevance: 4/5 (slight deviation)
✓ Completeness: 5/5 (all points)
✓ Format: 3/5 (partial formatting)
✓ Tone: 5/5 (perfectly professional)

Total score: 22/25 (88%)

sections.title: Systematic Iteration
sections.content: Proceed with cycles: Test → Measure → Analyze → Modify → Repeat. Document each iteration and results. Maintain a baseline to compare improvements.
sections.example:
Baseline (v1.0): Score 65%
→ Added examples (v1.1): Score 72% (+7%)
→ Specified format (v1.2): Score 78% (+6%)
→ Optimized temperature (v1.3): Score 85% (+7%)
→ Refined context (v2.0): Score 91% (+6%)

sections.title: Versioning and Documentation
sections.content: Use semantic versioning (v1.0, v1.1, v2.0) for prompts. Document: purpose, parameters, input/output examples, performance, modification dates. Keep previous versions for rollback.

best-practices.title: Best Practices
best-practices.description: Golden rules, proven patterns and practical tips for writing prompts that always work.
best-practices.introduction: Following established best practices in prompt engineering ensures better, more consistent and predictable results in every situation.

sections.title: Be Clear and Specific
sections.content: Avoid ambiguity. Use precise language. Specify exactly what you want, in what format, with what tone. More details = better results.
sections.example:
Bad: "Write something about marketing"

Good: "Write an 800-word article about digital marketing for B2C e-commerce. Include: introduction (100 words), 3 strategies with examples (200 words each), conclusion with CTA (100 words). Tone: professional but accessible. Target: Italian small business owners."

sections.title: Provide Sufficient Context
sections.content: The model doesn't know your background, industry, audience or objectives. Always provide relevant context: who you are, who the output is for, what the purpose is.
sections.example:
Bad: "Create a presentation"

Good: "I'm the CMO of a B2B SaaS startup in the HR tech sector. I need to present our new AI recruiting feature to 50 HR managers from Fortune 500 companies. Create a 15-slide presentation structure for a 20-minute session."

sections.title: Specify Output Format
sections.content: Don't let the model decide the format. Specify: numbered list, bullet points, JSON, table, narrative paragraph, etc. Include an example if possible.

sections.title: Use Delimiters and Structure
sections.content: Use clear delimiters (###, ---, """) to separate prompt sections. Use numbers for lists. This helps the model distinguish instructions, examples and input.

sections.title: Iterate and Refine
sections.content: The first prompt is rarely perfect. Analyze the output, identify what's missing or wrong, and refine. It's a normal and necessary iterative process.
sections.example:
V1: Output too generic
→ Add specific examples

V2: Tone too formal
→ Specify "conversational tone"

V3: Missing technical details
→ Add "include technical specifications"

V4: Perfect!

sections.title: Manage Expectations
sections.content: AI models have limits: they can invent facts (hallucination), don't know recent events, don't have real opinions. Don't ask for the impossible and always validate critical outputs.

casi-uso.title: Practical Use Cases
casi-uso.description: Real application examples: content marketing, technical documentation, customer service and coding assistant.
casi-uso.introduction: Practical and concrete examples of how to apply prompt engineering frameworks in real professional scenarios.

sections.title: Content Marketing
sections.content: Use frameworks like AIDA or ROSES to create engaging marketing content. Always specify audience, tone, length and desired CTA.

sections.title: Code Generation
sections.content: For generating code, be extremely specific: language, version, libraries, patterns, error handling, tests. Use expected input/output examples.

sections.title: Data Analysis
sections.content: For data analysis, provide context about the dataset, important metrics and type of insights sought. Specify output format (table, graph, narrative).

sections.title: Customer Service
sections.content: For automating customer service responses, define tone, company policies, response template. Use Few-Shot with real conversation examples.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.description: Quick solutions to the most common problems: inconsistent outputs, hallucinations, formatting and model limits.
troubleshooting.introduction: When prompts don't work as expected, systematic diagnosis and applying the right troubleshooting techniques solve most problems.

sections.title: Inconsistent Outputs
sections.content: If you get different results every time: reduce temperature (0.2-0.5), add more constraints and examples, use structured format, specify exact length.
sections.example:
Problem: Each run produces different length

Solution:
Bad: "Write a summary"
Good: "Write a summary of EXACTLY 150 words (±5 words). If the count isn't exact, rephrase."

Add: temperature=0.3, top_p=0.9

sections.title: Hallucinations (Invented Facts)
sections.content: The model invents information? Ask for sources, use "based only on", provide complete context, enable "search" if available, always validate critical outputs.
sections.example:
Problem: Invents statistics or quotes

Solution:
"Analyze this report. IMPORTANT:
- Use ONLY data present in the provided document
- If information is not in the text, write 'N/A'
- Do NOT make assumptions or estimates
- Cite the exact section for each datum"

sections.title: Format Not Followed
sections.content: If the model ignores the requested format: use clear delimiters, provide exact format example, require validation, use regex or JSON schema for parsing.

sections.title: Handling Edge Cases
sections.content: For unexpected inputs or edge cases: add input validation, specify behavior for edge cases, test on diverse dataset.
sections.example:
Common edge cases:

1. Empty input
→ "If input is empty, return: {error: 'No input provided'}"

2. Input too long
→ "If input > 5000 words, summarize first, then process"

3. Unexpected language
→ "If input is not in English, translate first, then process"

sections.title: Token Limits
sections.content: If you exceed limits: use chunking (divide input), summarize progressively, use models with larger context window, implement prompt chaining.

sections.title: Systematic Debugging
sections.content: Methodical approach: 1) Isolate the problem (which part fails?), 2) Simplify prompt to minimum, 3) Add complexity gradually, 4) Test each change, 5) Document what works.
